text:
Hi, there üëã

This presentation aims to organize our research efforts in a way that makes them transparent, reproducible, and in accordance with the best international standards.
Here is our itinerary:

Issues regarding the Global Syndemic project
Introduction to some concepts
A mini-tour into the open science world
Example of a reproducible research
Suggestions for the Global Syndemic project
Final remarks

title: Open science
section: Some issues regarding the Global Syndemic project
text:
Some issues regarding the Global Syndemic project

Lack of standards and guidelines regarding data collection, storage, analysis and sharing.
Lack of a project and data management system.
Need of sophisticated tools and techniques to analyze big datasets.

title: Open science
text:
What I can help with
It‚Äôs important to note, that I‚Äôm not an expert in public health or environmental science. However, I have a strong background in data science and complex systems modeling. I can help with:



Project management.
Data engineering.



Data analysis and visualization.
Complex system modeling.



I leave the theorizing and interpretation efforts to the experts in the field.

title: Open science
text: Introduction to some concepts

title: Open science
text:
Houston, we have a problem‚Ä¶

‚ÄúThe scientific research enterprise is built on a foundation of trust. Scientists trust that the results reported by others are valid. Society trusts that the results of research reflect an honest attempt by scientists to describe the world accurately and without bias. But this trust will endure only if the scientific community devotes itself to exemplifying and transmitting the values associated with ethical scientific conduct.‚Äù


(National Academy of Sciences et al., 2009)

Refraining from sharing data and code.
Not providing a clear description of the methods used.
Hierarchical communication.
Non-transparent research process.
Unreproducible results.
Lack of data management plan.
Lack of data documentation.
Data Findability ‚ùå
Data Accessibility ‚ùå
Data Interoperability ‚ùå (the data is locked in proprietary formats)
Data Reusability ‚ùå

(not to mention the toxic environment‚Ä¶)

title: Open science
text: A real fiction example

title: Open science
text:
There‚Äôs a solution: Open Science


‚ÄúOpen Science is an umbrella term encompassing a multitude of assumptions about the future of knowledge creation and dissemination.‚Äù (Fecher & Friesike, 2014)
At a high-level, it can be defined as the following.
‚ÄúOpen Science is scholarly research that is collaborative, transparent and reproducible and whose outputs are publicly available.‚Äù (European Commission & Directorate-General for Research and Innovation, 2018)








(Figure by Lotta Tomasson)

title: Open science
text:
Fair principles
Findability, Accessibility, Interoperability, and Reuse of digital assets.

(To learn more see: Wilkinson et al. (2016) and GO FAIR initiative (n.d.))

title: Open science
text:
What is data after all?


Ackoff‚Äôs DIKW pyramid.
Data < Information < Knowledge < Wisdom.
Data versus the interpretation of data.



(To learn more see: Ackoff (1989) and Rowley (2007))

title: Open science
text:
What is data after all?
Data is an abstraction of reality. It‚Äôs a representation of the world around us. Without context, it has no meaning.

title: Open science
text:
Data engineering
‚ÄúData engineering is the development, implementation, and maintenance of systems and processes that take in raw data and produce high-quality, consistent information that supports downstream use cases, such as analysis and machine learning.‚Äù
You can think data engineering as the plumbing of data science.





(Reis & Housley, 2022)

title: Open science
text:
Data science
It‚Äôs a confusing term, with many definitions and interpretations.
For some, data science is just statistics (Broman, 2013) (hype statistics). For others, it‚Äôs a new interdisciplinary field that synthesizes statistics, informatics, computing, communication, management, and sociology (Cao, 2017).
The arguments about the difference between data science and statistics are not very good. So it‚Äôs best to use a high-level definition:
‚ÄúData science is the study of the generalizable extraction of knowledge from data.‚Äù (Dhar, 2023)


(Figure extracted from Wickham et al. (2023))

title: Open science
text:
Data engineering versus data science

‚ÄúData scientists, according to interviews and expert estimates, spend from 50 percent to 80 percent of their time mired in this more mundane labor of collecting and preparing unruly digital data, before it can be explored for useful nuggets.‚Äù (Lohr, 2014).



(Figure by Reis & Housley (2022))

title: Open science
text:
Open Science Framework (OSF)
OSF is a free and open source project management tool that supports researchers throughout their entire project lifecycle.


(Center for Open Science)

title: Open science
text:
OSF: Components
‚ö†Ô∏è NOT FINISHED ‚ö†Ô∏è
Everything is a component in OSF, including projects.

title: Open science
text:
OSF: Managing permissions
OSF let you have a fine control over each component of your project.

title: Open science
text:
Open licenses
A unlicensed work is an ‚Äúall rights reserved‚Äù work. This means that you can‚Äôt use it without the author‚Äôs permission.

Licences for data

Open Knowledge Foundation


Licences for software/code

OSI Approved Licenses
The MIT licence
GNU General Public License version 3


Licences for everything else (e.g., documents, figures)

Creative Commons
CC BY 4.0

title: Open science
section: Python is fine too, I suppose‚Ä¶
text:
Python is fine too, I suppose‚Ä¶
Python is good for learning how to program, but it is much easier to learn how to work with data in R. In academia, both programming languages are very important.

title: Open science
section: Some other things that we didn‚Äôt cover
text:
Some other things that we didn‚Äôt cover
We just scratched the surface of the open science world. There are many other tools and concepts that we didn‚Äôt cover, such as:



Pipelines (e.g., targets).
Reproducible environments (e.g., renv, Docker).
Markup languages (e.g., Markdown, LaTeX).
Open source softwares (e.g., rOpenSci, CRAN, Bioconductor, PyPI).
Version control systems (e.g.¬†Git, SVN, Semantic versioning).
Open source data management systems (e.g., CKAN, Dataverse).
Open journals (e.g., PLoS, BMJ Open, PeerJ).
Community-driven open journals (e.g., Journal of Statistical Software, JASSS).



Preprint servers (e.g., arXiv, bioRxiv, OSF preprints).
Git-based repositories (e.g., GitHub, GitLab).
Open repositories (e.g., Zenodo, FigShare, ResearchGate, Dryad).
Data repositories (e.g., GSA, UniProtKB, OpenNeuro).
Open science policies (e.g., FAPESP, European Commission).
Shadow libraries (e.g., Sci-Hub, Library Genesis).

title: Open science
section: Suggestions for the Global Syndemic project
text:
Suggestions for the Global Syndemic project
‚ö†Ô∏è NOT FINISHED ‚ö†Ô∏è
Project and data management

Use OSF as a project and data management system


Implement OSF (Open Science Framework) as the central system for managing the project and associated data.


Subprojects integration


Integrate each subproject (e.g., scope review, data analysis, causal model, agent-based modeling) into the main project on OSF.

title: Open science
section: Suggestions for the Global Syndemic project
text:
Suggestions for the Global Syndemic project
Project and data management

Protocol registration


Register research protocols for both the main project and each subproject.
Ensure alignment of protocols before registration by using drafts.


Open licenses


Apply open licenses to both the data and the code to ensure transparency and accessibility.

title: Open science
section: Suggestions for the Global Syndemic project
text:
Suggestions for the Global Syndemic project
‚ö†Ô∏è NOT FINISHED ‚ö†Ô∏è
Data analysis

Use Wickham‚Äôs program for data analysis


Follow the guidelines and methodologies proposed by Wickham (2023) when conducting data analyses.
Tidy and document all the code and data.


Dynamic documents


Utilize dynamic documents to maintain an updated and reproducible record of data analyses.

title: Open science
section: Suggestions for the Global Syndemic project
text:
Suggestions for the Global Syndemic project
‚ö†Ô∏è NOT FINISHED ‚ö†Ô∏è
Data analysis

Programmatic approach


Emphasize learning and applying programmatic methods for handling large datasets, as this is the most effective approach for managing and analyzing extensive data collections


Reproducible environments


Use reproducible environments to ensure that the data analysis is replicable and transparent.

title: Open science

We need to work as a team
You‚Äôre not alone in this journey. We‚Äôre all in this together.
